properties.areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Interior Valleys
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 22 at 3:02PM PST until February 23 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Snow and icy road conditions expected. Total snow
accumulations of a dusting to one inch on the valley floor and 1
to 2 inches in the foothills. Snow levels will lower to around
1500 feet tonight. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph will also
cause dangerous wind chill readings and locally reduced
visibilities in blowing snow.

* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Interior Valleys.

* WHEN...Until noon PST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...This will be the coldest storm that we have seen so
far this winter season, with the potential for widespread
snow/ice impacts across many of our lower elevation passes which
could make for difficult travel with potential delays or road
closures. Major roadways that will likely have snow/ice impacts
include Highways 41, 46, and 58. Interior portions of Highway
101 may also experience a dusting of snow on Tuesday night.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

The latest road conditions from CalTrans are available by calling
1 800 4 2 7 7 6 2 3.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PST WEDNESDAY

properties.areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Mountains; Santa Barbara County Mountains; Ventura County Mountains; Los Angeles County Mountains excluding the Santa Monica Range
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 22 at 3:02PM PST until February 23 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Snow and icy road conditions expected. Total snow
accumulations of 1 to 3 inches expected across the mountains,
with local amounts up to 5 inches possible. Snow level falling
to 2000 feet and locally lower later tonight into Wednesday
morning. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph will also cause
dangerous wind chill readings and locally reduced visibilities
in blowing snow.

* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Mountains, Santa Barbara County
Mountains, Ventura County Mountains and Los Angeles County
Mountains excluding the Santa Monica Range.

* WHEN...Until noon PST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...This will be the coldest storm that we have seen so
far this winter season, with the potential for widespread
snow/ice impacts across many of our lower elevation passes which
could make for difficult travel with potential delays or road
closures. Major roadways that will likely have snow/ice impacts
include a large portion of Interstate 5 from the Grapevine to
Castaic, Highway 14 through the Soledad Canyon, and Highway 33
across the Ventura county mountains.
properties.instruction:
If traveling to the mountains, please remember to bring extra
food, warm clothing, and chains. Slow down and use caution while
traveling.

The latest road conditions from CalTrans are available by calling
1 800 4 2 7 7 6 2 3.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PST WEDNESDAY

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 22 at 4:57PM CST by NWS New Orleans LA
properties.description:
At 456 PM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7
miles southwest of Tylertown, or 16 miles northwest of Franklinton,
moving northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and a brief funnel cloud.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

Locations impacted include...
Tylertown and Salem.
properties.instruction:
If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.

If you see a funnel cloud. Move indoors and take shelter until the
storm passes.

properties.areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast
properties.headline: Freeze Warning issued February 22 at 2:44PM PST until February 24 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the first Freeze Warning, sub-freezing temperatures
as low as 22 expected. For the second Freeze Warning, sub-
freezing temperatures as low as 26 expected.

* WHERE...The coast within Douglas, Coos and Curry County.

* WHEN...For the first Freeze Warning, from 10 PM this evening
to 10 AM PST Wednesday. For the second Freeze Warning, from 10
PM Wednesday to 9 AM PST Thursday.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions will kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Temperatures will trend warmer slightly on
Wednesday night.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold. To prevent
freezing and possible bursting of outdoor water pipes they should
be wrapped, drained, or allowed to drip slowly. Those that have
in-ground sprinkler systems should drain them and cover above-
ground pipes to protect them from freezing.

feet expected.

* WHERE...Pt St George to Cape Mendocino 10 to 60 nm.

vessel for severe conditions.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 22 at 4:31PM CST until February 22 at 6:30PM CST by NWS Nashville TN
properties.description:

* WHERE...A portion of Middle Tennessee, including the following
counties, Davidson, Hickman, Lewis, Maury, Perry, Rutherford,
Wayne, Williamson and Wilson.

* WHEN...Until 630 PM CST.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...

thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin
shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain
have fallen in the last 24 hours, and additional rainfall
this evening will increase the risk of flooding.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Murfreesboro, Franklin, Columbia, Lebanon, Hohenwald,
Centerville, Linden, Smyrna, Brentwood, La Vergne, Spring
Hill, Mount Juliet, Nolensville, Forest Hills, Mount
Pleasant, Oak Hill, Thompson's Station, Fairview, Antioch and
Rural Hill.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:

deaths occur in vehicles.

properties.areaDesc: Coastal waters from Port Mansfield TX to the Rio Grande River out 20 NM; Coastal waters from Baffin Bay to Port Mansfield TX out 20 NM
properties.headline: Marine Weather Statement issued February 22 at 4:19PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
Latest visible satellite imagery and webcams from South Padre
Island shows areas of fog and patchy dense fog over the near
shore Gulf waters. Visibility of 1 to 3 miles can be expected in
most areas, with locally dense fog providing visibility to 1
nautical mile or less at times. The fog is expected to persist
through the evening and overnight.

Mariners should be prepared for abrupt visibility changes down to
one nautical mile or less. Use proper fog signals. Make sure all
running lights are on. Remember to use your radar and compass.

NWSheadline: PATCHY DENSE FOG OVER THE NEARSHORE COASTAL WATERS

western portions of Orange County.

Drivers need to be alert for rapidly changing visibilities,
maintain a safe distance from their vehicle and the one ahead, and
to use low beam headlights.

properties.areaDesc: Oak Point to Saxon Harbor WI; Outer Apostle Islands Beyond 5 NM from Mainland
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued February 22 at 4:01PM CST until February 23 at 4:00AM CST by NWS Duluth MN
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Heavy Freezing Spray Warning, heavy freezing
spray at a rate of 2 cm per hour or greater may rapidly
accumulate on vessels. For the Small Craft Advisory, north
winds 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 35 kt and waves 4 to 7 ft.

* WHERE...Oak Point to Saxon Harbor WI and Outer Apostle Islands
Beyond 5 NM from Mainland.

* WHEN...Until 4 AM CST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Operating a vessel in heavy freezing spray is
hazardous. Freezing spray may render mechanical and electronic
components inoperative. Rapid ice accretion on decks and
superstructures may result in a catastrophic loss of
stability. Conditions will be hazardous to small craft.
properties.instruction:
Mariners should prepare for dangerous accumulation of ice on
their vessel. If possible, remain in port, avoid the warning area
or conduct mitigation.

Anyone operating a smaller vessel should avoid navigating in
hazardous conditions.

properties.headline: Freeze Warning issued February 22 at 1:48PM PST until February 25 at 9:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Areas of sub-freezing temperatures in the overnight and
early morning hours.

* WHERE...Santa Clara Valley Including San Jose, coldest in the
southern Santa Clara valley including Gilroy and Morgan Hill.

* WHEN...From 2 AM Wednesday to 9 AM PST Friday.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions will kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The coldest temperatures will likely
occur Thursday morning when lows drop into the mid 20 in the
coldest portions of the North Bay Valleys and interior
Monterey County.
properties.instruction:
Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold. To prevent
freezing and possible bursting of outdoor water pipes they should
be wrapped, drained, or allowed to drip slowly. Those that have
in-ground sprinkler systems should drain them and cover above-
ground pipes to protect them from freezing.

creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 22 at 2:32PM CST by NWS Lubbock TX
properties.description:
AAA

A cold front which passed through West Texas early this morning
has brought sharply colder temperatures to the region. Temperatures
will fall tonight into the single digits across the northern
South Plains and southwestern Texas Panhandle while wind speeds
remain around 15 to 20 mph. This will set the stage for very cold
wind chill values of -5 to -15 degrees. A wind chill advisory has
been posted for these areas. Elsewhere, while the wind chill will
not be quite as frigid, it will remain quite uncomfortable.

For tonight and Wednesday night, freezing drizzle is expected to
develop and overspread areas east of the US Highway 385 corridor
with light ice or possibly snow grain/sleet accumulations across
the Rolling Plains. With the low temperatures in place, travel may
become hazardous especially on bridges and overpasses. Too, care
should be exercised while walking as sidewalks and elevated
objects may accumulate a light glaze as well.

Conditions are expected to improve by late Thursday morning as
temperatures rise to above freezing.

properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy mixed precipitation expected. Total snow
accumulations up to one inch, sleet accumulations around 1 inch,
and ice accumulations around four tenths of an inch.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest Illinois. Portions of southeast
Missouri.

* WHEN...From Noon Wednesday to Midnight CST Thursday Night.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Significant ice accumulation on
power lines and tree limbs may cause widespread and long-lasting
power outages. Power outages and tree damage are likely due to the
ice. Travel could be nearly impossible. The hazardous conditions
could impact the Wednesday evening and Thursday morning commutes.
properties.instruction:
If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in
your vehicle in case of an emergency. In Illinois, the latest road
conditions can be obtained at www.gettingaroundillinois.com. In
Missouri, the latest road conditions can be obtained at
traveler.modot.org/map or by calling 1-888-275-6636.

Persons should delay all travel if possible. If travel is absolutely
necessary, drive with extreme caution and be prepared for sudden
changes in visibility. Leave plenty of room between you and the
motorist ahead of you, and allow extra time to reach your
destination. Avoid sudden braking or acceleration, and be especially
cautious on hills or when making turns. Make sure your car is
winterized and in good working order.

Travel will become dangerous once the freezing rain begins. Travel
is strongly discouraged unless it is an emergency. Avoid any downed
power lines and be ready in case of a loss of power. Untreated roads
and bridges, sidewalks, and parking lots will be treacherous.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 22 at 2:01PM CST by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
properties.description:
A strong cold front will move into the northeastern Permian Basin
today, and continues through the rest of West Texas and Southeast
New Mexico tonight. Freezing drizzle will be possible behind the
front after midnight tonight, mainly over the eastern Permian
Basin. This may mix with sleet Wednesday morning as an upper
level disturbance arrives over the region. A second round of
freezing drizzle and sleet is expected across the eastern Permian
Basin Wednesday night into Thursday morning as the main trough
moves into the region. At this time, ice accumulations are
expected to be light, mainly a few hundredths of an inch, and
mainly on elevated surfaces, bridges, and overpasses. Motorists
should exercise caution by slowing down and increasing following
distances.

properties.description:

patchy freezing drizzle. Patchy slick spots may develop on some

further cooling into the 20s. Leave extra time to reach your
destination through this evening and drive with caution.

properties.headline: Hard Freeze Warning issued February 22 at 11:30AM PST until February 23 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Eureka CA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 20 expected.

* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast and
Mendocino Coast Counties.

* WHEN...From 1 AM to 9 AM PST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions will kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.
properties.instruction:
Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold. To prevent
freezing and possible bursting of outdoor water pipes they should
be wrapped, drained, or allowed to drip slowly. Those that have
in-ground sprinkler systems should drain them and cover above-
ground pipes to protect them from freezing.

Frost Advisories and Freeze Warnings are issued during the local
growing season as defined by climatology and local agriculture
experts. Once the growing season has ended these statements will
no longer be issued until the spring.

properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued February 22 at 12:23PM MST until February 23 at 7:00PM MST by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in El Paso TX/Santa Teresa has
issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from noon to 7 PM
MST Wednesday.

* AFFECTED AREA...Fire weather zones 111 and 112 in southwest and
south-central New Mexico. Fire weather zone 055 in far west
Texas.

* WIND...Southwest winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.

* HUMIDITY...8 to 15 percent

* HIGHEST THREAT...is located along the Rio Grande Valley across
Sierra, Dona Ana, and Luna Counties.

* IMPACTS...any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
properties.instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.

NWSheadline: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 7 PM MST WEDNESDAY FOR STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 055, 111, AND 112

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 22 at 10:25AM PST by NWS Reno NV
properties.description:
* Scattered snow showers continue today as a broad area of low
pressure moves overhead. This could also allow lake effect bands
to form on the southern side of Lake Tahoe and Pyramid Lake
where localized heavier snowfall rates and accumulations are
possible. Most snow showers will begin to taper off tonight.

* As a cold air mass moves in, light and powdery snow could be
prone to blowing and drifting with reductions in visibility
possible. The cold temperatures could also keep area roads and
walkways snow covered and icy. Be sure to check with CalTrans
and NDOT for the latest road conditions before heading out.

* A cold air mass will give us the potential to see some of the
coldest temperatures of the season thus far. Anticipate
widespread teen and single digit low temperatures, with below
zero temperatures in colder Sierra valleys. Overnight lows look
to be coldest tonight and Wednesday night, especially Wednesday
night as skies begin to clear out. High temperatures through
Wednesday are unlikely to get out of the 30s, even in the
warmest of valleys, with teens and 20s in the mountains.

properties.headline: Avalanche Advisory issued February 22 at 6:37AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
properties.description:
The following message is transmitted at the request of the
Hatcher Pass Avalanche Center.


...THE HATCHER PASS AVALANCHE CENTER HAS ISSUED AN AVALANCHE
WARNING...

* WHAT...The avalanche danger is high. Very dangerous avalanche
conditions exist. Travel in avalanche terrain is NOT recommended

* WHERE...Skeetawk / mile 11 to Independence Mine, including Gold
Mint and Archangel Valley

* WHEN...In effect from Tuesday 700 AKST to Wednesday 700 AKST.

* IMPACTS...An additional 2 to 3 inches of SWE and 18 to 24 inches
of snow has accumulated over the last 24hrs. Snowfall should
taper by 6pm Tuesday. Large to very large human triggered
avalanches are very likely and natural avalanches are likely on
slopes steeper than 30 degrees. Debris from avalanches above may
run into valley bottoms.

* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS..Travel in avalanche
terrain is not recommended. Backcountry travelers should stay
off of and out from underneath slopes steeper than 30 degrees.
Avalanches may run long distances. Avoid avalanche terrain.
Consult http://www.hpavalanche.org/ or www.avalanche.org for
more detailed information. The Hatcher Pass Road remains closed
at mile 11 due to avalanche activity.



For more information visit hpavalanche.org.

properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued February 22 at 10:27AM EST until February 23 at 3:00AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...Southern Brevard, Indian River, St. Lucie, Martin,
Coastal Volusia and Northern Brevard Counties.

* WHEN...Through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as jetties and
piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.areaDesc: Northern Oregon Cascades; Cascades in Lane County; South Washington Cascades
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 22 at 4:53AM PST by NWS Portland OR
properties.description:
A late season push of arctic air is spreading into the region this
morning, along with increasing east to northeast winds.
Temperatures have already fallen into the lower to middle teens
this morning on the Cascade passes, trending toward single digits
for the ski resort elevations. Combined with winds gusting up to
40 mph, the resulting wind chills will be below zero at times for
the passes through Wednesday.

Even colder wind chills are likely for the higher ski resort
elevations, where the combination of single digit temperatures and
blustery winds will make it feel like 10 to 15 degrees below
zero. Such wind chills can cause frostbite on exposed skin within
30 minutes.

Anyone heading up to the Cascades should be prepared for colder
temperatures than usual. Drivers should be sure to have a winter
weather kit in their vehicle, along with blankets and plenty of
fuel.

NWSheadline: BITTERLY COLD WIND CHILLS IN THE CASCADES THROUGH WEDNESDAY

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Willacy; Coastal Cameron; Coastal Kenedy
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued February 22 at 5:34AM CST until February 22 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected.

* WHERE...Coastal Willacy, Coastal Cameron and Coastal Kenedy
Counties.

* WHEN...Through this afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON

properties.headline: Hard Freeze Watch issued February 22 at 3:03AM PST until February 24 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Wind Advisory, west winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts
up to 35 mph expected. For the Hard Freeze Watch, sub-freezing
temperatures as low as 24 are possible.

* WHERE...Ventura County Interior Valleys.

* WHEN...For the Wind Advisory, from 8 AM this morning to 6 PM
PST this evening. For the Hard Freeze Watch, from late tonight
through Thursday morning.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects and
make driving difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may
result. Freezing conditions could kill crops, other sensitive
vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.
properties.instruction:
Use extra caution when driving, especially if operating a high
profile vehicle. Secure outdoor objects.

Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold. To prevent
freezing and possible bursting of outdoor water pipes they should
be wrapped, drained, or allowed to drip slowly. Those that have
in-ground sprinkler systems should drain them and cover above-
ground pipes to protect them from freezing.

NWSheadline: WIND ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM THIS MORNING TO 6 PM PST THIS EVENING... ...HARD FREEZE WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Northern Lea County; Central Lea County; Southern Lea County; Gaines; Dawson; Borden; Scurry; Andrews; Martin; Howard; Mitchell; Ector; Midland; Glasscock; Upton; Reagan
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 22 at 4:36AM CST by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
properties.description:
A strong cold front will move into the Western Low Rolling Plains
today, and through the rest of West Texas and Southeast New Mexico
tonight. Freezing drizzle will be possible behind the front after
midnight tonight, mainly over the Western Low Rolling Plains, as
well as the northern and central Permian Basin. This may mix with
sleet Wednesday night and Thursday morning as an upper level
disturbance arrives over the region.  At this time, ice
accumulations are expected to be light...under a tenth of an
inch...and mainly on elevated surfaces, bridges, and overpasses.
Motorists should exercise caution by slowing down and increasing
following distances.

NWSheadline: A WINTRY MIX OF LIGHT PRECIPITATION POSSIBLE TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY MORNING

properties.description:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 20 possible.

* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast and
Mendocino Coast Counties.

* WHEN...From late tonight through Wednesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.
properties.instruction:
Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold. To prevent
freezing and possible bursting of outdoor water pipes they should
be wrapped, drained, or allowed to drip slowly. Those that have
in-ground sprinkler systems should drain them and cover above-
ground pipes to protect them from freezing.

Frost Advisories and Freeze Warnings are issued during the local
growing season as defined by climatology and local agriculture
experts. Once the growing season has ended these statements will
no longer be issued until the spring.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued February 21 at 8:02PM CST until February 26 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Birmingham AL
properties.description:
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Tombigbee River At Bevill Lock and Dam.

* WHEN...From Wednesday morning to Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...At 122.0 feet, Cattle in low-lying areas of Southern
Pickens County should be moved to higher ground. Cattle are cutoff
in lowlands of Southern Pickens County at stages above 122 feet.
At 128.0 feet, Cattle in the area should be moved to higher
ground. Flooding of some cabins and camps along the river can be
expected.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 6:00 PM CST Monday the stage was 113.7 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage
Wednesday morning to a crest of 124.2 feet early Thursday
afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage Friday
evening.
- Flood stage is 122.0 feet.

properties.areaDesc: Matagorda Islands; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula
properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued February 21 at 5:47PM CST until February 22 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected along Gulf facing beaches.

* WHERE...Matagorda Islands, Brazoria Islands, Galveston Island
and Bolivar Peninsula.

* WHEN...Through Tuesday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

NWSheadline: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON

properties.areaDesc: Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains
properties.headline: Avalanche Watch issued February 21 at 3:17PM MST by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE
COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.

* WHAT...Avalanche Watch

* WHERE... CAIC Forecast Zone of Aspen and Gunnison.

* WHEN... Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected to
develop by Tuesday afternoon and last through at least
Wednesday.

* IMPACTS... Heavy snow and strong winds will result in natural
avalanches.  Large human-triggered avalanches are likely as new
snow accumulates.
properties.instruction:
Monitor
Colorado.gov/avalanche for changing conditions.
Plan ahead for avalanche conditions to become very dangerous, and
to avoid travel in avalanche terrain by late Tuesday afternoon.

JK

properties.headline: The Winter Storm Watch has been replaced. Please see the latest information from NWS Las Vegas NV on this developing situation.
properties.description: The Winter Storm Watch has been replaced. Please see the latest information from NWS Las Vegas NV on this developing situation.
properties.instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads

properties.areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast
properties.headline: Freeze Warning issued February 21 at 3:09AM PST until February 23 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures in the 20s.

* WHERE...South Central Oregon Coast and Curry County Coast.

* WHEN...From 10 PM Tuesday to 10 AM PST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Freeze conditions will kill crops, other sensitive
vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Forecast temperatures will likely be very
unusual for this time of year with record lows near or below
freezing in the Brookings area.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
Take steps to protect tender plants from the cold. To prevent
freezing and possible bursting of outdoor water pipes they should
be wrapped, drained, or allowed to drip slowly. Those that have
in-ground sprinkler systems should drain them and cover above-
ground pipes to protect them from freezing.

NWSheadline: FREEZE WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 10 PM TUESDAY TO 10 AM PST WEDNESDAY

properties.areaDesc: Northwest Plateau; Northwest Deserts; Lincoln County
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued February 21 at 1:04AM PST until February 23 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Las Vegas NV
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible above 3000 feet. Total snow
accumulations of 1 to 7 inches possible. Winds could gust as
high as 40 mph.

* WHERE...In Arizona, Northwest Plateau and Northwest Deserts.
In Nevada, Lincoln County.

* WHEN...From Tuesday morning through Wednesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
properties.instruction:
A Winter Storm Watch means there is potential for significant
snow accumulations that may impact travel. Continue to monitor
the latest forecasts.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING ABOVE 3000 FEET

properties.headline: Winter Storm Warning issued February 21 at 2:03AM MST until February 22 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 10
and 17 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.

* WHERE...Tusas Mountains Including Chama.

* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 5 PM MST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult
to impossible. Some roads may be closed. Significant travel delays
are possible.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Areas of blowing snow may reduce visibility
on area roadways, such as U.S. Highway 64.
properties.instruction:
If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in
your vehicle in case of an emergency. For the latest road
conditions, dial 511 or 1.800.432.4269, or visit http://nmroads.com.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 5 PM MST TUESDAY

properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 21 at 2:46AM CST until February 22 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Omaha/Valley NE
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow expected. Total
snow accumulations of up to two inches. Winds gusting as high as
35 mph with considerable blowing snow. For the Wind Chill
Advisory, very cold wind chills expected. Wind chills as low as
25 below zero.

* WHERE...Knox and Cedar Counties.

* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, from 6 PM this evening
to 6 PM CST Tuesday. For the Wind Chill Advisory, from
midnight tonight to noon CST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions and reduced
visibilities due to blowing snow. The hazardous conditions
could impact the morning or evening commute. The cold wind
chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30
minutes.
properties.instruction:
Use caution while traveling, and have a winter safety kit in your
car.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO 6 PM CST TUESDAY... ...WIND CHILL ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO NOON CST TUESDAY

properties.areaDesc: Fleming; Montgomery; Bath; Rowan; Estill; Powell; Menifee; Rockcastle; Jackson; Pulaski; Laurel; Wayne; McCreary; Whitley; Knox; Bell; Harlan; Elliott; Morgan; Johnson; Wolfe; Magoffin; Floyd; Lee; Breathitt; Knott; Owsley; Perry; Clay; Leslie; Letcher; Martin; Pike
properties.headline: Flood Watch issued February 21 at 3:40AM EST until February 23 at 6:00AM EST by NWS Jackson KY
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall possible.

* WHERE...Portions of east central Kentucky, northeast Kentucky,
south central Kentucky and southeast Kentucky, including the
following counties, in east central Kentucky, Bath, Elliott,
Estill, Fleming, Menifee, Montgomery, Powell and Rowan. In
northeast Kentucky, Johnson and Martin. In south central Kentucky,
Laurel, McCreary, Pulaski, Rockcastle, Wayne and Whitley. In
southeast Kentucky, Bell, Breathitt, Clay, Floyd, Harlan, Jackson,
Knott, Knox, Lee, Leslie, Letcher, Magoffin, Morgan, Owsley,
Perry, Pike and Wolfe.

* WHEN...From late tonight through late Tuesday night.

* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,
creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- A slow-moving cold front will bring widespread rain to
eastern
Kentucky from tonight through late Tuesday night. The rain
could be
heavy at times on Tuesday into Tuesday night. At this time,
1.5 to 3
inches of rainfall is forecast to fall. Should these rainfall
amounts materialize, flooding of some creeks and streams will
be a good bet
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood
Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared
to take action should flooding develop.

NWSheadline: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH LATE TUESDAY NIGHT

properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued February 21 at 1:28AM MST until February 23 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the High Wind Warning, southwest winds 30 to 40 mph
with gusts up to 65 mph expected. For the Blowing Dust Advisory,
visibility between one quarter mile and one mile in blowing dust
expected. For the fisrt Wind Advisory, southwest winds 25 to 35
mph with gusts up to 55 mph expected. For the second Wind
Advisory, southwest winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 55 mph
expected.

* WHERE...Southwest corner of Imperial County.

* WHEN...For the High Wind Warning, from 1 PM this afternoon to
midnight PST tonight. For the Blowing Dust Advisory, from 10 AM
this morning to 7 PM PST this evening. For the first Wind
Advisory, from 6 AM this morning to 1 PM PST this afternoon. For
the second Wind Advisory, from midnight tonight to 4 AM PST
Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions due to reduced
visibility. Very difficult driving conditions, especially for
larger vehicles traveling along roads with crosswinds. Light,
unsecured objects will become airborne. Moderate tree and
minor structural damage possible.
properties.instruction:
Be ready for a sudden drop in visibility. If you encounter
blowing dust or blowing sand on the roadway or see it
approaching, pull off the road as far as possible and put your
vehicle in park. Turn the lights all the way off and keep your
foot off the brake pedal.

Remember, pull aside, stay alive.

A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage. In addition,
strong winds over desert areas could result in briefly lowered
visibilities to well under a mile at times in blowing dust or
blowing sand. Use extra caution.

* WHAT...West winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 50 mph

* WHERE...Indian Wells Valley, Mojave Desert Slopes, and Mojave
Desert in southeastern Kern County.

* WHEN...From 10 AM Monday to 10 PM PST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects. Tree
limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
Highways impacted include, but are not limited to, 14, 58, 178,
and U.S. 395.
properties.instruction:
Use extra caution when driving, especially if operating a high
profile vehicle. Secure outdoor objects.
